repnme.cdata!:
Serbia and Montenegro - Montenegro
            Environmental Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project has been assessed with a
            satisfactory project outcome, likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impacts, and
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower. Lessons
            of experience are conveyed as follows. The Bank should
            actively promote the regional landfill model, i.e., multiple
            municipalities disposing their solid waste in a regional
            sanitary landfill, managed by companies owned by the
            municipalities and national government, for replication
            throughout Montenegro. However, agreeing to a landfill
            location is a complicated and prolonged process, for which
            the Bank can be instrumental in helping stakeholders reach a
            solution that maximizes the benefits. Throughout the
            process, the Bank should offer its services as an honest
            broker, but avoid being drawn into the fight that will
            inevitably occur during the process. Notably, all
            stakeholders should be involved and consulted extensively,
            particularly the local communities that will bear most of
            the costs. The Bank can help reach solutions in its capacity
            to draw on international independent experts that offer
            non-biased technical opinions. A consultant credible to all
            parties, must complete all technical aspects and
            environmental and social impact assessment.

repnme.cdata!:
Clean drinking water returns to
            Montenegro's Zeta valley

abstracts.cdata!:
The situation spurred Montenegro's
            authorities to decide to build a new water system, one that
            will connect the valley with the capital, Podgorica. The
            World Bank financed the purchase of pipes and other
            equipment through a United States (U.S.) $ 668,000 grant.
            The Government of Montenegro and municipal agencies
            contributed funds as well. This was the first World Bank
            project in Montenegro, after Serbia and Montenegro (then the
            Federal Republic of Yugoslavia) rejoined the Bank on May 8, 2001.

5087641.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Yugoslavia, Federal Republic of -
            Montenegro Environmental Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Montenegro Environmental
            Infrastructure Project aims at improving the environmental
            conditions in the coastal region of Montenegro, as well as
            the quality of water supply in, and around the capital city
            of Podgorica. The project components will: 1) finance the
            rehabilitation of the multi-municipal Kotor landfill site,
            to meet sanitary standards. Such rehabilitation will
            comprise, other than a new fence, and gate, a groundwater
            monitoring system, leakage treatment, and a gas collecting
            system. A new compactor and bulldozer will be provided, to
            allow an adequate landfill operation, while drainage systems
            will be installed to control degassing, and drainage. In
            addition solid waste equipment will be financed to institute
            long-term environmental monitoring, maintain, and manage the
            landfill site; 2) finance the completion of the water supply
            pipeline construction, thus replacing contaminated water
            sources in the Zeta Valley, with water from the Podgorica
            municipal water supply system; and, 3) support project
            implementation, through the provision of funds for the
            completion of engineering services, and for auditing of
            project accounts.

repnme.cdata!:
Yugoslavia, Federal Republic of -
            Montenegro Coastal Urgent Municipal Environmental
            Infrastructure Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental management plan (EMP)
            seeks to minimize potential environmental adversity caused
            by the implementation of the Montenegro Coastal Municipal
            Environmental Infrastructure Project, namely in the areas of
            waste disposal, health and safety issues, and emission
            control. Mitigation measures call for a working plan to deal
            with key health, safety, and environmental issues, including
            enforcement of monitoring criteria on quality assurance
            procedures, compliant with health and safety regulations, in
            accordance with prevailing environmental legislation.
            Facilities will be designed to contain wastes, subject to
            waste inspection, and clearance, thereby undertaking sample
            testing for final disposal, or processing. Traffic will
            undergo, as appropriate, a one-way system to avoid
            congestion. Shredding, and waste conveying will be conducted
            to ensure dust emissions are controlled, either by spraying,
            or covering top layers, in addition to contingency plans on
            alternative arrangements for the transfer of waste to the
            energy cell. Upon excavation of energy cells, decomposed
            material should be disposed of at distant selected sites, in
            accordance with standard environmental procedures. Emission
            standards are recommended to be applied for surface, and
            groundwater quality, landfill gas explosives, and
            occupational exposure limits, as well as for noise
            disturbances, following monitoring requirements. Vegetative
            propagation will be ensured to provide visual screening, and
            control air pollution.
